note.p: Letter not found. For the text given here, see 'Notes and Queries', Australasian, 1 April 1865, p. 8.

p.seg: kindly forwarded the following answer to "X.Y.Z.'s" question:

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The question has not been found.

p.seg: —"I do not see how, theoretically the fact of the fruits getting no stones in the way described could be explained; nor have I practically witnessed the effects of such a method. Fruits become seedless by luxuriant cultivation under certain circumstances, but only certain kinds—the succulent portion becoming more strongly developed."]

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: The same article has another answer supplied by M., but it is not clear that it was in the form of a letter or memo:

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 9pt; margin-left: 0.6681in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in;

note.p: SOLARUM.—Dr. Mueller says :—" I am not aware to what other tubers as edible Mr. Duffield could have alluded, but to certain peculiar varieties of potato, or some kind of the ordinary tropical yam."

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3346in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3346in; font-size: 9pt;
